parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can increase soil organic matter on agricultural land.
[Statement 2]: Growing cover crops beneath the main crop or between crop rows has been shown to increase soil organic matter.
[Statement 3]: Using crop rotation increases soil organic matter.
[Statement 4]: Including legumes in crop rotation increases soil organic matter.
[Statement 5]: Adding below-ground organic matter through compost applications increases soil organic matter content.
[Statement 6]: Adding below-ground organic matter through manure applications increases soil organic matter content.
[Statement 7]: Amendments with manures and agricultural composts have positive effects on soil organic matter.
[Statement 8]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments can increase soil organic matter.
[Statement 9]: Growing green manure crops increases soil organic carbon.
[Statement 10]: Changing tillage practices to reduced tillage systems maintains or increases soil organic matter.
[Statement 11]: Using no-tillage systems maintains or increases soil organic matter.
[Statement 12]: Amending soil with bacteria has been found to increase soil organic matter content.
[Statement 13]: Amending soil with fungi, specifically arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi, has been found to increase soil organic matter content.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions can be taken to increase soil organic matter on agricultural land?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Reducing the use of fertilizer, pesticide, or herbicide is beneficial for increasing the diversity of soil organisms.
[Statement 2]: Low-input systems with reduced fertilizer, pesticide, or herbicide use showed a higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms.
[Statement 3]: Converting to organic farming demonstrated higher numbers, diversity, functional diversity or activity of soil organisms.
[Statement 4]: Using crop rotation increased the number of microbes and the diversity of different soil animals.
[Statement 5]: The inclusion of legumes in crop rotations was particularly beneficial for increasing the number of microbes and the diversity of different soil animals.
[Statement 6]: Changing tillage practices showed mixed results for soil organism diversity.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found that reduced tillage resulted in more microbes, more species of earthworm, or higher microbe activity.
[Statement 8]: Excluding grazers from areas was found to increase nematode diversity.
[Statement 9]: Studies on inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding or planting focused more on vegetation responses rather than on the diversity of soil organisms.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Which actions are most beneficial for increasing the diversity of soil organisms?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Compost application increased soil organic matter levels, microbial biomass, and fruit yield.
[Statement 2]: High rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss.
[Statement 3]: Manures and agricultural composts resulted in higher microbial biomass and respiration.
[Statement 4]: Manures and agricultural composts reduced nutrient loss and led to higher nitrogen levels.
[Statement 5]: Manures and agricultural composts resulted in higher soil organic carbon levels.
[Statement 6]: Manures and agricultural composts increased crop yields.
[Statement 7]: Fresh plant material or crop residues increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 8]: Fresh plant material or crop residues reduced soil loss.
[Statement 9]: Fresh plant material or crop residues resulted in higher soil nitrogen levels and carbon storage.
[Statement 10]: Straw incorporation improved soil structure.
[Statement 11]: Straw incorporation increased barley yield.
[Statement 12]: Green manures grown as soil amendments increased soil organic carbon.
[Statement 13]: Green manures grown as soil amendments increased grain yields.
[Statement 14]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments showed higher microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 15]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments reduced soil cracking.
[Statement 16]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments increased soil organic carbon levels.
[Statement 17]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments improved maize yield.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the effects of amending soil with different types of organic materials?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Besides retaining crop residues, what other actions can reduce soil erosion on agricultural land with clay soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Multiple actions can reduce soil erosion on agricultural land with clay soils.
[Statement 2]: Adding mulch to crops increases soil stability on clay soils.
[Statement 3]: Adding mulch to crops reduces soil erosion on clay soils.
[Statement 4]: Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards or vineyards reduces soil erosion on clay soils compared to bare or tilled soils.
[Statement 5]: Changing tillage practices to reduced or no-tillage systems shows mixed results for reducing soil loss on clay soils.
[Statement 6]: Reduced or no-tillage systems generally reduce soil loss on clay soils when crop cover is present.
[Statement 7]: Planting grass buffer strips or margins around fields helps reduce soil erosion at field edges.
[Statement 8]: Using crop rotation that includes forage crops reduces rainwater runoff.
[Statement 9]: Using crop rotation that includes forage crops reduces soil loss.
[Statement 10]: Reducing grazing intensity helps control soil compaction on clay soils.
[Statement 11]: Reducing grazing intensity reduces sediment erosion on clay soils.
[Statement 12]: Amending soil with organic materials like fresh plant material or crop remains can improve soil structure.
[Statement 13]: Amending soil with organic materials like fresh plant material or crop remains can reduce erosion susceptibility.
[Statement 14]: Adding mulch can improve soil structure.
[Statement 15]: Adding mulch can reduce erosion susceptibility.

[Statement 1]: Evidence from Asia shows that mixed organic and inorganic soil amendments are effective for improving crop yields.
[Statement 2]: Trials from China found increased maize yields in soils with mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments.
[Statement 3]: Soil amendments with crops grown as green manures showed higher soil organic carbon in studies from India and Pakistan.
[Statement 4]: Soil amendments with crops grown as green manures increased grain yields in studies from India and Pakistan.
[Statement 5]: The incorporation of fresh plant material and crop remains improved yields.
[Statement 6]: A trial from the Philippines found higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season.
[Statement 7]: Studies from India, Spain and Turkey found higher crop yields when manures or agricultural composts were applied.
[Statement 8]: Bacterial and fungal amendments showed positive results in trials from India and Turkey, leading to higher crop yields.
[Statement 9]: Formulated chemical compounds, or fertilizers, showed yield increases in trials from India and the Philippines.
[Statement 10]: In India and the Philippines, maize, wheat and rice yields increased with increased fertilizer application.
[Statement 11]: In Italy, soil amendments with composts not otherwise specified increased fruit yield.
[Statement 12]: Evidence indicates that organic amendments like manure, compost, and green manures are particularly effective for improving crop yields across various Asian countries.
[Statement 13]: Mixed organic-inorganic combinations are particularly effective for improving crop yields across Asian countries including China, India, Pakistan, and the Philippines.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of different soil amendments for improving crop yields on farms in Asia?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several effective actions can reduce nitrate loss from agricultural soils.
[Statement 2]: Growing cover crops in arable fields can reduce nitrate leaching from soils compared to soils without cover crops.
[Statement 3]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty can also reduce nitrate leaching.
[Statement 4]: Changing the timing of ploughing by delaying the ploughing until spring can reduce nitrate leaching.
[Statement 5]: Amending the soil with formulated chemical compounds, specifically nitrification inhibitors, can be effective in reducing nitrate losses.
[Statement 6]: The method of application for nitrification inhibitors can influence the effect on reducing nitrate losses.
[Statement 7]: Amending the soil with manures and agricultural composts has shown mixed results for nitrate leaching.
[Statement 8]: The application of farmyard or poultry manure can reduce nutrient loss.
[Statement 9]: Some studies have found higher nitrate leaching after amending soil with manures and agricultural composts.
[Statement 10]: Changing tillage practices has revealed mixed effects on nitrogen levels.
[Statement 11]: No-till soil can have less carbon and nitrate compared to conventionally tilled soil.
[Statement 12]: Conventionally tilled soil can lose more carbon and nitrate overall than no-till soil.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions can be taken to reduce nutrient loss, specifically nitrates, from agricultural soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Comprehensive research findings identify actions that are consistently beneficial for both increasing soil organic carbon and improving biodiversity.
[Statement 2]: Amending soil with organic materials shows the strongest dual benefits for increasing soil organic carbon and improving biodiversity.
[Statement 3]: Adding fresh plant material or crop remains consistently increased soil organic carbon.
[Statement 4]: Adding fresh plant material or crop remains also increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 5]: Amending soil with manures and agricultural composts increased soil organic carbon.
[Statement 6]: Amending soil with manures and agricultural composts also increased microbial biomass and diversity.
[Statement 7]: Crop residue retention demonstrated positive effects for both soil organic carbon and biodiversity.
[Statement 8]: Higher soil organic carbon was found in randomized trials when crop residues were retained.
[Statement 9]: Retaining crop residues also showed increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 10]: Cover cropping proved effective by increasing soil carbon levels.
[Statement 11]: Cover cropping resulted in more diverse nematode communities.
[Statement 12]: Cover cropping resulted in greater microbial biomass under different cover crop systems.
[Statement 13]: Reduced or no-tillage systems showed strong evidence for increasing soil organic carbon.
[Statement 14]: Studies found reduced or no-tillage systems increased the numbers of soil animals and earthworms.
[Statement 15]: Reduced or no-tillage systems led to higher microbial diversity and activity.
[Statement 16]: Using mixed organic and inorganic amendments provided dual benefits for soil organic carbon and biodiversity.
[Statement 17]: Four trials found more organic carbon in soils when using mixed organic and inorganic amendments.
[Statement 18]: Five controlled trials found higher microbial biomass and activity when using mixed organic and inorganic amendments.
[Statement 19]: Crop rotation increased soil organic carbon.
[Statement 20]: Crop rotation also increased microbial numbers and the diversity of different soil animals.
[Statement 21]: Specific agricultural actions consistently demonstrate positive outcomes for both soil organic carbon sequestration and biodiversity enhancement across multiple peer-reviewed studies worldwide.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Which actions are most consistently beneficial for both increasing soil organic carbon and improving biodiversity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains like straw can improve silty-clay soil structure.
[Statement 2]: Adding mulch to crops, such as straw or municipal compost, can increase soil stability.
[Statement 3]: Adding mulch to crops can reduce erosion.
[Statement 4]: Studies from India, France, Nigeria and the UK have shown that adding mulch to crops results in increased soil stability and reduced runoff.
[Statement 5]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure.
[Statement 6]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves nutrient retention.
[Statement 7]: Three randomized studies from Denmark, Turkey and the UK found that growing cover crops improved soil structure and resulted in higher soil porosity.
[Statement 8]: Changing tillage practices, such as switching from conventional tillage to no-tillage, can improve soil aggregation and stability.
[Statement 9]: Seven replicated studies from Spain and the USA found that untilled soils were more stable than tilled soils.
[Statement 10]: Using crop rotation, particularly including legumes and forage crops, can improve soil structure.
[Statement 11]: Using crop rotation can increase water infiltration.
[Statement 12]: One replicated trial from Syria showed increased water infiltration when legumes were included in a crop rotation.
[Statement 13]: Retaining crop residues helps to reduce soil erosion.
[Statement 14]: Retaining crop residues helps to improve water storage.
[Statement 15]: A review found that retaining crop residues reduced water runoff, increased water storage, and reduced soil erosion.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__As an alternative to adding compost, what other actions can improve the soil structure of silty-clay soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Organic soil management practices serve as effective alternatives to chemical fertilizers for increasing crop yield.
[Statement 2]: The application of organic fertilizers such as manure and agricultural composts improved soil organic carbon levels and increased crop yields.
[Statement 3]: The use of green manures grown specifically to amend soil increased soil organic carbon and grain yields.
[Statement 4]: The incorporation of fresh plant material and crop residues improved soil organic carbon levels and increased crop yields.
[Statement 5]: Growing cover crops either beneath main crops or during field-empty periods enhanced soil organic matter.
[Statement 6]: Growing cover crops improved soil structure, increased nitrogen levels, and led to higher crop yields.
[Statement 7]: Implementing crop rotations, particularly those including legumes, increases soil organic carbon and water infiltration.
[Statement 8]: Crop rotations including legumes support higher microbial diversity.
[Statement 9]: Research shows organic soil management practices can maintain or improve crop yields compared to chemical fertilizers.
[Statement 10]: Studies have found higher yields in plots with organic fertilizers in some comparisons against chemical fertilizers.
[Statement 11]: Organic soil management practices provide additional benefits such as reduced soil erosion.
[Statement 12]: Organic soil management practices provide additional benefits such as improved water retention.
[Statement 13]: Organic soil management practices provide additional benefits such as enhanced biodiversity.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__As an alternative to using chemical fertilizers to increase crop yield, what organic soil management practices are shown to be effective?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions can improve soil structure by reducing compaction?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can improve soil structure by reducing compaction.
[Statement 2]: Reducing grazing intensity allows compacted soils to recover.
[Statement 3]: Excluding sheep for 2.5 years enabled compacted soils to recover.
[Statement 4]: Amending soil with organic processing wastes or composts can improve soil structure and reduce soil loss.
[Statement 5]: Applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure.
[Statement 6]: Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains was found to improve soil structure.
[Statement 7]: Straw incorporation was found to improve soil structure.
[Statement 8]: Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains also reduced soil loss.
[Statement 9]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty can improve soil structure and nutrient retention.
[Statement 10]: Soil under cover crops can have higher soil porosity, interconnectivity, and lower resistance.
[Statement 11]: Using brash mats during harvesting can help avoid soil compaction.
[Statement 12]: Reducing tillage intensity can improve soil aggregation and stability.
[Statement 13]: Using no tillage or reduced tillage instead of conventional tillage can improve soil aggregation and stability.
[Statement 14]: Soils without tillage were more stable than tilled soils.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the available evidence on how different soil amendments affect biodiversity in soils with a sandy loam texture?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from multiple studies shows various effects of soil amendments on biodiversity in sandy loam soils.
[Statement 2]: A mix of organic and inorganic amendments increased microbial biomass and activity in sandy loam soils.
[Statement 3]: In one trial, a mix of organic and inorganic amendments was also found to increase microbial diversity.
[Statement 4]: Adding bacteria or arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi resulted in higher microbial diversity in a trial on sandy loam soils.
[Statement 5]: Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains increased microbial biomass in sandy loam soils.
[Statement 6]: Manures and agricultural composts increased microbial biomass and respiration in sandy loam soils.
[Statement 7]: Municipal wastes and their composts showed mixed results in trials on sandy loam soils.
[Statement 8]: Organic processing wastes and their composts were tested in sandy loam soils.
[Statement 9]: One trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss.
[Statement 10]: Cover crops grown in sandy loam soils resulted in more diverse nematode communities.

[Statement 1]: Several actions can improve soil moisture and drought resilience on sandy soils as alternatives to adding mulch.
[Statement 2]: Amending the soil with manures and agricultural composts can improve soil structure and water retention by increasing soil organic matter and aggregation.
[Statement 3]: Amending the soil with manures and agricultural composts can increase soil organic carbon and improve soil physical properties.
[Statement 4]: Retaining crop residues reduces water runoff and increases water storage.
[Statement 5]: Retaining crop residues increases soil organic carbon and nitrogen levels.
[Statement 6]: Retaining crop residues is particularly effective for sandy-loam soils.
[Statement 7]: Growing cover crops or living mulches reduces soil erosion.
[Statement 8]: Growing cover crops or living mulches can increase soil organic matter.
[Statement 9]: Studies on sandy loam and sandy soils show the benefits of growing cover crops or living mulches.
[Statement 10]: Changing tillage practices can improve the soil's ability to absorb water.
[Statement 11]: Subsoiling can increase soil water content and is particularly relevant for drought conditions on sandy soils.
[Statement 12]: Amending soils with organic processing wastes or composts can improve soil structure on sandy loam soils.
[Statement 13]: Amending soils with organic processing wastes or composts can reduce soil loss and improve nutrient retention.
[Statement 14]: Alternatives to mulch work by adding organic matter to improve water-holding capacity.
[Statement 15]: Alternatives to mulch work by protecting the soil surface from evaporation.
[Statement 16]: Alternatives to mulch work by modifying soil structure to enhance water infiltration and storage.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__As an alternative to adding mulch, what actions can improve soil moisture and drought resilience on sandy soils?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the wider soil health effects of amending soils with animal-derived products like manure or composts?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Animal-derived soil amendments like manure and composts have demonstrated multiple beneficial effects on soil health.
[Statement 2]: Soils amended with manure or compost have consistently shown higher microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 3]: Higher microbial biomass and activity in amended soils indicate improved soil biodiversity.
[Statement 4]: Soil organic carbon levels increase with manure application.
[Statement 5]: Animal-derived soil amendments improve soil physical properties.
[Statement 6]: Trials have shown that animal-derived amendments result in enhanced soil structure.
[Statement 7]: Trials have shown that animal-derived amendments result in larger soil aggregations.
[Statement 8]: Trials have shown that animal-derived amendments result in reduced soil loss.
[Statement 9]: Nutrient retention improves with manure and compost application.
[Statement 10]: High application rates of manure and compost can potentially lead to increased nutrient loss.
[Statement 11]: The water retention capacity of soil increases with the use of amendments like manure and compost.
[Statement 12]: Research shows reduced water runoff following manure application.
[Statement 13]: Crop yields consistently improve with manure and compost amendments.
[Statement 14]: When combined with inorganic fertilizers, manure amendments show even greater benefits for microbial activity.
[Statement 15]: When combined with inorganic fertilizers, manure amendments show even greater benefits for soil organic carbon.

[Statement 1]: The documented evidence shows mixed effects of organic farming conversion.
[Statement 2]: For biodiversity outcomes, seven of eleven studies found organic arable farms had greater species richness of butterflies, burnet moths and all moths than conventional farms.
[Statement 3]: Some effects of organic farming on biodiversity were context-dependent, occurring only in intensively managed landscapes.
[Statement 4]: Some biodiversity effects of organic farming occurred in farms managed organically for less than 6 years but not in farms managed organically for 15-23 years.
[Statement 5]: Five of seven studies found more bat species on organic farms.
[Statement 6]: Five of nine studies found no difference in overall bat activity between organic and non-organic farms.
[Statement 7]: Three studies showed higher abundance of wild bees under organic farming.
[Statement 8]: Three studies found no difference in wild bee abundance under organic farming.
[Statement 9]: Soil and ecosystem benefits of organic farming included higher soil carbon levels in organically managed orchards compared to conventional management.
[Statement 10]: Four studies found higher numbers, diversity or activity of soil organisms under organic management.
[Statement 11]: One study found lower soil nutrients in organically managed soils.
[Statement 12]: Key drawbacks of converting to organic farming center on production and economics.
[Statement 13]: Six studies measuring yields from organic farming found mixed effects, with one finding a positive effect, one a negative effect, one mixed effects, and three showing no or inconsistent effects.
[Statement 14]: One study found net profit from organic farming increased only if produce received a premium.
[Statement 15]: The same study found that if produce did not receive a premium, profit from organic farming decreased.
[Statement 16]: Another study found yields were lower in organically managed soils.
[Statement 17]: Studies specifically on organic fertilizers showed mixed effects on yields.
[Statement 18]: Some studies found higher yields with organic fertilizer, others found lower yields, and some found similar yields.
[Statement 19]: Two studies showed low-input systems had a higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms.
[Statement 20]: Stopping fertilizer inputs in grasslands increased plant species richness and invertebrate abundance in six studies.
[Statement 21]: One study found lower nutrient levels and yields in low-input systems.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the documented benefits and drawbacks of converting to low-input or organic farming systems?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In Europe, several alternatives to conventional ploughing can improve soil structure.
[Statement 2]: Reduced tillage systems maintain or increase soil organic matter compared to conventional ploughing.
[Statement 3]: Reduced tillage systems improve soil structure compared to conventional ploughing.
[Statement 4]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure.
[Statement 5]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves nutrient retention.
[Statement 6]: Studies show growing cover crops results in higher soil porosity, interconnectivity, and lower resistance.
[Statement 7]: Soil amendments using organic materials also enhance soil structure.
[Statement 8]: Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains improves soil structure.
[Statement 9]: Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains creates larger soil aggregates.
[Statement 10]: Amending soil with organic processing wastes or composts improves soil structure.
[Statement 11]: Amending soil with organic processing wastes or composts reduces soil loss.
[Statement 12]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments are more effective at reducing soil cracks than fertilizers alone.
[Statement 13]: Alternatives to conventional ploughing work by increasing soil organic carbon.
[Statement 14]: Alternatives to conventional ploughing work by enhancing microbial biomass.
[Statement 15]: Alternatives to conventional ploughing work by creating better soil aggregation.
[Statement 16]: Increased soil organic carbon, enhanced microbial biomass, and better soil aggregation collectively improve soil structure without the need for conventional ploughing.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__In Europe, what alternatives to conventional ploughing can improve soil structure?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Adding compost to soil increases microbial biomass compared to applying no compost.
[Statement 2]: Amending soil with a mix of organic and inorganic amendments can increase microbial biomass.
[Statement 3]: The use of manure and inorganic fertilizer combinations leads to higher microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 4]: Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains increases microbial biomass.
[Statement 5]: The addition of crop remains and straw to soil increases microbial biomass.
[Statement 6]: Retaining crop residues results in higher microbial biomass.
[Statement 7]: Using reduced tillage leads to more microbial biomass in soils compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 8]: Using no tillage as the main cultivation method results in higher microbial biomass.
[Statement 9]: Soils without tillage have higher microbial biomass compared to soils with tillage.
[Statement 10]: Growing cover crops or maintaining ground cover leads to more microbial biomass compared to bare or tilled soils.
[Statement 11]: The inclusion of cover crops in perennial systems increases microbial biomass.
[Statement 12]: Using crop rotations that include legumes can cause increases in microbial biomass.
[Statement 13]: Microbial biomass increases with crop rotations when compared to continuous cropping.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Which actions are most effective for increasing soil microbial biomass?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several effective methods for reducing soil erosion on agricultural land have been identified.
[Statement 2]: Adding mulch to crops has been shown in multiple studies to increase soil stability.
[Statement 3]: Adding mulch to crops has been shown in multiple studies to reduce soil erosion and runoff.
[Statement 4]: Mulches increased soil moisture in replicated trials.
[Statement 5]: Mulches improved yields in replicated trials.
[Statement 6]: Reducing grazing intensity was found to help soil recovery from compaction.
[Statement 7]: Reducing grazing intensity was found to reduce sediment erosion.
[Statement 8]: Studies show that excluding grazing animals increased soil carbon and nitrogen levels.
[Statement 9]: Studies show that excluding grazing animals reduced soil phosphate loss and sediment erosion.
[Statement 10]: Planting grass buffer strips and margins around fields can help reduce runoff and soil loss.
[Statement 11]: Nineteen studies from Europe show that planting grass buffer strips and margins provides benefits for biodiversity.
[Statement 12]: Planting grass buffer strips and margins around fields can help to filter runoff.
[Statement 13]: Using alley cropping, which involves intercropping with trees, was found to increase soil fungal diversity.
[Statement 14]: Practices for reducing soil erosion work by protecting soil surfaces and improving soil structure.
[Statement 15]: Practices for reducing soil erosion work by reducing runoff velocity.
[Statement 16]: Practices for reducing soil erosion work by increasing ground cover to prevent soil particles from being washed or blown away.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are some of the most effective actions for reducing soil erosion on agricultural land?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Manure application shows multiple benefits including higher microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 2]: Manure application, when combined with other treatments, can reduce soil loss and water runoff.
[Statement 3]: Manure application can enhance soil nutrient retention, leading to higher nitrogen levels.
[Statement 4]: Applying manure can increase soil organic carbon.
[Statement 5]: The application of manure can improve soil organic matter and physical properties.
[Statement 6]: Manure application can lead to higher crop yields.
[Statement 7]: A documented drawback of manure application is the potential for higher nitrate leaching in some cases.
[Statement 8]: Manure application can increase nutrient runoff, causing more dissolved organic carbon, nitrate, ammonium, phosphorus, and potassium to be leached from soils.
[Statement 9]: Municipal waste applications can greatly reduce soil loss and water runoff in semi-arid soils.
[Statement 10]: The application of municipal waste can increase soil organic matter.
[Statement 11]: A drawback of municipal waste applications is that they have shown mixed results in some cases.
[Statement 12]: The application of municipal waste can increase nitrate levels in soil.
[Statement 13]: Soils with added sewage sludge can have higher carbon dioxide emissions compared to untreated soils.
[Statement 14]: Digested sewage sludge resulted in more soil nitrate compared to composted or thermally dried forms of sewage sludge.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__On agricultural land, what are the documented benefits and drawbacks of amending soil with manures or municipal wastes?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions are available to improve the physical structure of clay and clay-loam soils.
[Statement 2]: Adding organic amendments, including composts and organic processing wastes, is highly effective for improving soil.
[Statement 3]: Adding fresh plant material or crop remains is a highly effective way to improve soil.
[Statement 4]: Adding manures with agricultural composts is a highly effective way to improve soil.
[Statement 5]: The addition of organic amendments improves soil structure.
[Statement 6]: The addition of organic amendments increases soil organic carbon.
[Statement 7]: The addition of organic amendments creates larger soil aggregates.
[Statement 8]: The addition of organic amendments enhances nutrient retention.
[Statement 9]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure.
[Statement 10]: Growing cover crops increases soil porosity and interconnectivity.
[Statement 11]: Growing cover crops reduces soil compaction.
[Statement 12]: Changing tillage practices can reduce soil compaction, though results vary between studies.
[Statement 13]: Adding mulch to crops increases soil stability.
[Statement 14]: Adding mulch to crops reduces erosion.
[Statement 15]: Amending soil with a mix of organic and inorganic amendments effectively reduces crack size in dry clay soils.
[Statement 16]: Growing green manures increases soil organic carbon in clay loam soils.
[Statement 17]: Adding gypsum to soil can improve soil conditions for planting.
[Statement 18]: Actions to improve soil structure have been tested on various clay and clay-loam soil types.
[Statement 19]: The tested actions demonstrate measurable improvements in the physical properties of soil.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions are available to improve the physical structure of clay and clay-loam soils?
